column4: This is a recording of the overtone scale over a steady fundamental (F#3), going up and down from the 4th harmonic to as high as the 12th harmonic

Similar recording of the overtone scale over a steady pitch (C#4). The key difference is that the louder overtones made it more challenging to detect the fundamental pitch without harmonic interference.
Recording of a changing fundamental melody while keeping a constant pitch in the second overtone melody.
First of the three main styles of Mongolian throat singing, low frequency style, the pitch detection algorithms have trouble detecting this  low-freq sound (~69Hz)
The second style in traditional Mongolian throat singing, mid frequency range, still the algorithm has issues detecting such low frequencies.
High frequency Mongolian throat singing style, more in line with western overtone singing, this style is better suited for this algorithm. This recording features more expressive overtone dynamics.
This recording, similar to the above, reaches higher overtones
This recording features a fundamental melody line, and the 4th harmonic parallel to the fundamental
The same concept as above, but with the 6th harmonic parallel to the fundamental melody line.
An overtone melody line over changing fundamentals changing in steps.
An overtone melody line over changing fundamentals changing in steps, reaching higher harmonics and changing timing.
An overtone melody line over changing fundamentals changing in steps, reaching higher harmonics, changing timing and adding more complexity in the end.
Decreasing pitch fundamental melody line with increasing pitch overtone melody line and vice-versa.
Same concept as above, in a major mode.
Performance of a full folk song using overtone polyphony.
